newsitem.title: UK: Middle East tanker rates edge down, quiet.
newsitem.headline: Middle East tanker rates edge down, quiet.

text.p: Middle East dirty tanker rates edged down in quiet Monday trade, brokers said.

Very large crude carriers (VLCCs) from the Middle East were generally fixed about 2.5 Worldscale points lower than on Friday, with voyages west at about W50, to Japan at W60/61 and to Singapore at W50 for older vessels and W60 for modern ships, one broker said.
"There are quite a few ships out there and a lack of steady enquiry," he added.
The Mediterranean 80,000 tonne sector, which soared in mid-January, continued to soften to around W135 in thin trade.

"There are cargoes to be fixed but it's not an easy market right now and it's hard to get a firm idea of rates," an Italian broker said. He said the rate for 130,000 tonne cross-Med vessels remained about W95.
Brokers said North Sea-U.S. Gulf cargoes were assessed slightly lower at W60 for VLCCs and W90 for 130,000 tonners -- about 2.5 points down in both cases -- but few fixtures were seen.
West Africa/USG VLCCs were steady at W62.5, while 130,000 tonne vessels were hard to pin down in a thin market, although brokers said one had been fixed at W90 late on Friday against W95 previously.
The inter-U.K./Cont market was extremely quiet with 80,000 tonners still notionally at about W110.
The market for fuel oil cargoes was active with a firm tone, brokers said. Inter-U.K./Cont 25,000 tonners were steady at W205 and cross-Med at W190.
In the U.S. sector, rates were steady with 70,000 tonnes Caribs/upcoast at W155 and 50,000 tonne fuel oil cargoes at W165/170. "Rates really haven't changed much since Wednesday," one broker noted.
